body: The Rev. Vincent Fusco, the senior minister at a charismatic church in Brooklyn, donated a storehouse of food -- bottled water, dried eggs, powdered milk, canned tuna and vegetables -- to the down-and-out, since the arrival of the year 2000 did not cast the world into a calamitous dusk. David Boser, once the co-owner of the Survival Preparedness
title: For Y2K Doomsayers, The End Is Not Near

body: Eugenia Sitaras knew she had the winning numbers for half of a $130 million jackpot, but she did not alert New York State Lottery officials right away. ''I had other things to take care of,'' said Ms. Sitaras, 26, a kindergarten teacher in Brooklyn. Ms. Sitaras, who is known as Eve, had lesson plans to prepare and parent-teacher conferences to
title: Teacher Has Arithmetic to Do: What's Half of $130 Million?

body: A 46-year-old Japanese method for teaching mathematics that demands nothing less than 100 percent scores before students move on to new material has been setting up tutoring outposts in immigrant and middle-class neighborhoods of New York City. The Kumon method, which quickly swept Japan and now enrolls 2.6 million students on six continents, holds
title: EDUCATION; Japanese Math Program Tallies Success With Discipline

body: ATTRACTIONS Museums and Sites ALICE AUSTEN HOUSE, 2 Hylan Boulevard, Rosebank, Staten Island. This 17th-century farmhouse, converted to a Victorian cottage in the 19th century, was the home of the photographer Alice Austen. ''Ferryboat,'' photographs by Charles Martin, through Dec. 31. Hours: Thursdays through Sundays, noon to 5 p.m. Admission: $2;
title: SPARE TIMES

body: HARBOR seals bobbing in the water. Freighters from all over the world floating by. Cormorants spreading their wings on pier pilings and diving for fish. A sandy beach, right in the backyard. This is Brooklyn? Dr. June Reinisch, 57, and her husband, Dr. Leonard Rosenblum, 64, have been privy to these views of Gravesend Bay -- sometimes using a
title: If You're Thinking of Living In/Sea Gate; 'Hamptons West' in Brooklyn

body: It is the kind of most-wanted list that could make more than a few car owners sympathize with the criminal element: the 21 New Yorkers who owe the most in unpaid parking tickets. That sympathy might fade, however, with the revelation of the grand totals. The city's Department of Finance, as part of a new strategy of trying to pressure
title: New York Names Names of Biggest Parking-Ticket Scofflaws

body: For years, the authorities and some of his neighbors say, Arthur Alalouf lived a reclusive life in Gravesend, Brooklyn, sulking in his parents' home at 16 Parkway Court. He kept a shabby room in his parents' basement. He took Xanax, a prescription drug used to calm anxiety. He was known to swear loudly at his several large dogs, sometimes shouting
title: Before Attack on Officers, Arsenal and Combat Dress

body: A deranged man barricaded in his Brooklyn home with a small arsenal of weapons wounded a police officer with a shotgun blast yesterday afternoon and, after a tense six-hour siege with surrounding police sharpshooters, was killed in a backyard gun battle that left two more officers wounded last night, the police said. On a day that illustrated again
title: BROOKLYN GUNMAN WOUNDS 3 OFFICERS BEFORE BEING SLAIN

body: THE word Sahara may conjure up images of rolling dunes and head-splitting heat, but in Gravesend, Brooklyn, Sahara is an oasis. In the summer, this sprawling Turkish restaurant offers a lovely garden in the rear where you can dine like the luckiest of desert dwellers, under trellises thick with grapevines, surrounded by squash and cucumber plants.
title: TO GO; In the Brooklyn Desert, a Cool Sahara

body: About 50 parents, teachers and students protested yesterday in front of the Board of Education headquarters, expressing anger that the board had not renewed the contract of a popular district superintendent in south Brooklyn. Donald Weber, superintendent of District 21 for 17 years, resigned on July 5, five days after his contract expired.
title: Protest Backs Schools Chief In Brooklyn

body: If you are dying for a good steak, and you are thinking about Denny's Steak Pub in Kensington, Brooklyn, you might as well come in a hearse. ''We got your clams and scampi, scungilli, veal,'' Tom DeRosa says. ''My chili's good, but we don't got no steak.'' Mr. DeRosa, 55, is the chef de cuisine, whose resume includes Joe's Bar on Avenue U in
title: NEIGHBORHOOD REPORT: BENDING ELBOWS; A Steak Pub Missing a Central Ingredient: Steak

body: Barnard Expands Creative Writing Program Drawing on New York City's wealth of literary talent, Barnard College is starting a creative writing program this fall that will use noted authors as teachers. JHUMPA LAHIRI, a Barnard graduate who won the Pulitzer Prize for fiction this year with ''Interpreter of Maladies,'' is already lined up. Two
title: BULLETIN BOARD

body: Under a steamy cloud-bound sky, one of the largest gatherings of seagoing vessels since man first lashed a cut of canvas to a mast cruised majestically across the watery parade ground of New York Harbor yesterday in a tribute to America's 224th year of independence. A stately march of 26 tall ships, hulls humming and sails rippling, led an 11-mile
title: SALUTING THE FOURTH: THE OVERVIEW; Tall Ships Render a Stately Tribute to Independence

body: Precisely at 11 a.m. Saturday, the Nassau, an amphibious-helicopter carrier, passed under the Verrazano-Narrows Bridge into Upper New York Bay. The ship was headed for its turn at the diesel ballet, a maneuver in which four tugboats nudge their hulking gray partner into its appointed anchorage southwest of Red Hook, Brooklyn. The low-slung black
title: Coast Guard Choreographs Harbor's Biggest Gathering

body: ''How do you say the name?'' Sal Carr asked as he eased the motorboat through the Marine Basin Marina in Brooklyn Saturday evening and out into Gravesend Bay. title: Overdue, and Broke, Ukraine's Ship Comes In

body: The F train rattled above McDonald Avenue, tossing glints of twilight at the storefronts of Gravesend. It was another dusk in southern Brooklyn, a time when a young man's thoughts turn toward the night ahead and those of an old mob lawyer toward the nights that have already gone by. Albert C. title: The Guy Who Defends Wise Guys

body: DO you like those arms?'' Tyce Keith D'Orio demanded of the student dancers trying to follow his moves at Horizons Dance Center in the Flatlands section of Brooklyn. ''I don't like those arms. They need to pop.'' The students tried again. About two dozen, teenagers and young adults, were jammed into the small studio, moving to the strains of Tracy
title: NEW YORKERS & CO.; Studios Nurture the Starry-Eyed and Twinkle-Toed

body: Mayor Rudolph W. Giuliani said yesterday that his administration's new plan to close the Fresh Kills landfill and ship the city's trash from existing waterfront stations would reduce truck traffic and not unfairly burden any city neighborhood. City Council leaders also praised the plan and promised to work to approve it quickly. Speaker Peter F.
title: Mayor Says New Trash Plan Will Reduce Truck Traffic

body: Nineteen-year-old twin brothers were found shot in the head early yesterday, their bodies dumped into the middle of a residential street in the Gravesend section of Brooklyn. Anthony and Charles DiGirolamo, who would have turned 20 next week, were found in front of 1794 West Fifth Street by a passer-by about 4:25 a.m., said Sgt. Elias Nikas, a
title: Twin Brothers Are Found Shot to Death, Their Bodies Dumped on a Brooklyn Street

body: 'TIS By Frank McCourt Scribner (Hardcover, $26) The first officer told me Albany was a city far up the Hudson River, capital of New York State. title: NEW YORK BOOKSHELF; An Immigrant's View, the Art of Trash, a Phantom's Lair: All Between Covers in 1999
